questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with acute, profuse, watery diarrhoea some days after returning from a holiday. Which one of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most likely cause of travellers' diarrhoea is E. coli. Ciprofloxacin would cover for this as well as Shigella, Salmonella and Campylobacter.
  • However, if giardiasis was cultured in the stool, then metronidazole is recommended.

Traveller’s diarrhoea:

  • Traveller’s diarrhoea is usually bacterial and rapidly responsive to a short course of fluoroquinolones.
  • Guidelines recommend ciprofloxacin (500 mg twice daily for 3 days or a single 750 mg dose) as first-line empirical therapy for moderate to severe non-dysenteric traveller's diarrhoea .
  • Most secretory forms of traveller's diarrhoea (usually due to enterotoxigenic or enteroaggregative E. coli or to Campylobacter) can be treated effectively with rehydration, bismuth subsalicylate, or antiperistaltic agents.
  • Antimicrobial agents can shorten the duration of illness from 3-4 days to 24-36 hours, but may be associated with the acquisition of multidrug-resistant organisms; their use should therefore be reserved for severe cases.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man has recently complained of fever, rigours and headache. On examination, he had a temperature of 38°C, a blood pressure of 120/70 mmHg, and a pulse of 110 bpm. His abdomen was tender in the right upper quadrant. Investigations showed:
Hb 10.5 g/dL
WBC 13500/μL
Neutrophils 11200/μl
Platelets 360000/μLBlood film No malaria parasites seen
Alk Phos 420 U/L
AST 60 U/L
CRP 110 mg/L
Stool culture Negative
Chest x-ray: Small right pleural effusion
Which of the following investigations would be of diagnostic value?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • For this clinical picture-fever, right upper quadrant tenderness, elevated ALP, systemic inflammation, and a small right pleural effusion—the most likely diagnosis is a pyogenic liver abscess.
  • The ultrasound would determine if there is a pyogenic liver abscess or an amoebic liver abscess.
  • The clinical history with associated pleural effusion suggests that an abscess needs to be excluded (and drained if necessary).

Pyogenic liver abscess:

Causes:

  • Predominantly polymicrobial infections involving E. coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Bacteroides, anaerobic streptococci, enterococci, and occasionally Staphylococci in bacteremia cases.

Symptoms:

  • Fever, chills, malaise, anorexia, weight loss, and right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain or discomfort are common.
  • Some patients may also present with pleuritic chest pain or right shoulder pain due to diaphragmatic irritation.

Signs:

  • RUQ tenderness, hepatomegaly, anaemia of chronic disease, occasional jaundice, and on chest X-ray, right-sided pleural effusion or elevated hemidiaphragm.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Anti‑endomysial antibody(Option B):  Used to diagnose celiac disease; here it is not indicated.

Typhoid serology(Option C): Typhoid fever rarely presents with isolated RUQ pain and abnormal LFTs as seen here.

Stool ova & parasites(Option D): More relevant for parasitic GI infections, not primary liver abscess with this biochemical and radiographic profile.

choices.text: Mesenteric angiography to exclude is ischemic colitis

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man has a 5-day history of abdominal pains and bloody diarrhoea. He is unwell on admission. Blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, and he has a tender abdomen on palpation. His Hb is 9.0 g/dl, white cell count 11,000/μL, and platelet count is 80000/μL. Urea is 70 mg/dl and creatinine 2.2mg/dl, sodium 137 mmol/l and potassium 5.5 mmol/l
Blood film shows red cell fragmentation and thrombocytopenia.
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the unifying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The diagnosis is HUS (haemolytic uraemic syndrome). The commonest causes are E coli O157:H7, but other pathogens are Campylobacter, Shigella and Clostridium.
  • There is classical renal failure, thrombocytopenia (HUS-TTP) and evidence of microangiopathic haemolysis on the blood film.

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome:

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a form of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) characterised by the triad of:

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia (with schistocytes/red cell fragmentation),
  • Thrombocytopenia, and
  • Acute kidney injury (AKI)

It most commonly occurs in two main forms:

  • Typical: Caused by Shigatoxin-producing E. coli.
  • Atypical: Caused by to genetic alteration of the complement pathway.

Management:

  • Typical: Supportive care is the mainstay. Antibiotics are contraindicated.
  • Atypical: Targeted therapy with monoclonal antibodies.

Explanation of other options:

CT scan of the abdomen(Option A): while useful for bowel pathology, not diagnostic for TMA/HUS and doesn't confirm the infectious trigger.

Amoxicillin and metronidazole(Option B): Empiric antibiotics are contraindicated in EHEC infection, as they may exacerbate toxin release and worsen HUS.

Mesenteric angiography(Option D): Relevant for ischemic colitis but not indicated in microangiopathic hemolysis; here, the pathophysiology is intravascular microthrombi rather than large-vessel ischemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man has previously been well, and there is no past medical history. He has a 5-day history of bloody diarrhoea and has acute abdominal pains. On examination, he has a temperature of 38°C and a tender lower abdomen. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bloody diarrhoea is more likely to be caused by Shigella.
  • Cholera and giardial diarrhoea are not typically bloody. (Option C and D ruled out.)
  • There is no history of immunocompromise to suggest cryptosporidium infection. (Option A ruled out.).

Shigellosis:

Transmission:

  • The most common is faecal-oral
  • Other modes include ingestion of contaminated food or water, contact with a contaminated inanimate object, and sexual contact.

Presentation: 

  • Sudden onset of severe abdominal cramping
  • high-grade fever
  • Emesis
  • anorexia
  • Large-volume watery diarrhoea

Complications:

  • Seizures
  • Delirium
  • Haemolytic uraemic syndrome
  • Treatment: 
  • Cotrimoxazole and ampicillin are recommended treatments.

Key takeaways:

Causes of bloody diarrhoea: 

Can be remembered as CHESSY.

  • Campylobacter jejuni
  • Enterohemorrhagic E. coli
  • Entamoeba histolytica
  • Shigella dysenteriae
  • Salmonella
  • Yersinia enterocolitis

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady presents with bilateral swelling and discomfort around her face. This caused her pain when she was chewing. It started 2 days ago, and she also has a mild fever and headache. She mentioned she had been in contact with someone with a similar illness 2 weeks ago. On examination, she has bilateral parotid enlargement, which is tender. Which of the following is a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fever, parotid swelling and pain during chewing indicate parotitis.
  • Bilateral parotitis is usually due to viral infection by the Mumps virus.
  • There are many causes of parotid swellings. Viruses include mumps, coxsackie A virus, parainfluenzae virus, CMV and varicella zoster virus.

Mumps:

  • The incubation period for mumps is usually 18 to 21 days.
  • Mumps is caused by a paramyxovirus and is spread from person to person by saliva droplets or direct contact with articles that have been contaminated with infected saliva.
  • The parotid glands (the salivary glands between the ear and the jaw) are usually involved.
  • Unvaccinated children between the ages of 2 and 12 are most commonly infected, but the infection can occur in other age groups.
  • Orchitis (swelling of the testes) occurs in 10-20% of infected males, but sterility only rarely ensues; a viral meningitis occurs in about 5% of those infected.

Explanation of the incorrect options:

Myotonic dystrophy(Option A):

  • This is a genetic muscular disorder characterised by myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation), facial muscle weakness, cataracts, and cardiac issues.
  • It does not cause acute, tender parotid gland swelling or fever.
  • Parotid gland tumours (like pleomorphic adenomas) may rarely occur in myotonic dystrophy, but those present as chronic, painless swellings, not acute, tender bilateral enlargement. 

Marfan’s syndrome(Option B):

  • A connective tissue disorder featuring tall stature, long limbs, lens dislocation, aortic aneurysms, and hyperflexible joints.
  • It has no association with parotid gland swelling, infection, or acute facial discomfort.

Multiple myeloma(Option C):

  • A plasma cell malignancy presenting with bone pain, anaemia, renal impairment, and hypercalcemia.
  • It does not typically involve the parotid glands, and you wouldn’t expect an acute tender swelling in the parotid area as a presenting feature

questions.text: A 36-year-old man has an HIV infection. Recently, his CD4 count has dropped to 250 from 600, and viral load has dropped from 1000 copies to 2000 copies /ml. He has now developed diarrhoea. Which one of the following is likely to cause diarrhoea in an HIV positive patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a patient where the CD4 count has dropped rapidly, infection with opportunistic pathogens has to be considered.
  • Cryptosporidia, microsporidia, and Isospora belli are the most common opportunistic protozoa that infect the GI tract and cause diarrhoea in HIV-infected patients.
  • Common organisms such as Entamoeba, Salmonella, Giardia, Campylobacter, Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, Mycobacterium and also viral causes can cause diarrhoea in HIV positive patients.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Staphylococcus aureus(Option A): Usually causes food poisoning—an acute, self-limiting toxin-mediated illness—and is not a common cause of chronic diarrhoea in HIV.

Streptococcus pyogenes(Option B): Causes pharyngitis, impetigo, and invasive infections—not diarrhoea.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis(Option D): Can cause intestinal TB infrequently, but more commonly affects the lungs and lymph nodes. Also, it's not a typical cause of profuse watery diarrhoea.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman has recently been treated with amoxicillin for a tooth abscess. Since then, she has developed diarrhoea up to 15 times a day. There is blood in the stools.Her Hb is 13 g/dl, WCC 13 x 10^9/l, platelets 500 x 10^9/L. Her CRP is 80 mg/l. What is the likely infective organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a patient who has recently had antibiotics, Clostridium difficile is the most likely infective organism.

Clindamycin, ampicillin, and cephalosporins are the implicated drugs.

Discontinuation of the offending antibiotic is important (not always easy if an infection such as a dental abscess persists).

Oral administration of fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the treatment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old Caucasian male presents with a six-month history of weight loss, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. On examination, you note finger clubbing. Which of the following diagnoses is least likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ileo-caecal TB is the only condition mentioned not associated with clubbing.

GI causes of clubbing:

  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Celiac disease
  • Cirrhosis
  • Neoplasms

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with the development of pseudomembranous colitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin. Commonly, the disease is caused by broad-spectrum antibiotics, most commonly cephalosporins, broad-spectrum penicillins and clindamycin.
  • Less commonly, macrolides and quinolones have been reported to cause the disorder.
  • Ciprofloxacin, Erythromycin and co-trimoxazole also cause Pseudomembranous colitis, but are less compared than cephalosporins. (Other options ruled out)

Pseudomembranous colitis:

  • Clostridium difficile, a Gram-positive anaerobic bacterium, is the cause of pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Severe watery diarrhoea, abdominal cramping, fever and nausea are the common clinical features.
  • Studies show that when C. difficile colonise the gut, it releases two potent toxins, toxin A and toxin B, which bind to certain receptors in the lining of the colon and ultimately cause diarrhoea and inflammation of the large intestine or colon (colitis).
  • Oral Vancomycin and Fidaxomycin are the agents used for mild infections.
  • Metronidazole is reserved for fulminant cases.

Key takeaways:

GI causes of clubbing:

  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Celiac disease
  • Cirrhosis
  • Neoplasms

questions.text: An 18-year-old student presents with a 15-week history of diarrhoea. He has lost 2 kg in weight, and has no recent travel abroad. A smear of a duodenal biopsy reveals trophozoites. What is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The diagnosis here is giardiasis, caused by Giardia lamblia.
  • Giardia has been reported as a cause of chronic diarrhoea.
  • Most patients respond to oral metronidazole 250-400 mg three times daily for five days.

Giardiasis:

  • Giardiasis is one of the most common protozoal infections worldwide, affecting around 280 million symptomatic individuals annually

Transmission occurs via:

  • Ingestion of cyst-contaminated water or food
  • Person-to-person contact, especially in childcare settings
  • Zoonotic transmission from animals to humans

Symptoms:

  • Watery, foul-smelling, fatty diarrhoea (steatorrhea)
  • Abdominal cramps, bloating, flatulence, gas
  • Nausea, anorexia, weight loss, excessive fatigue
  • Acquired lactose intolerance and malabsorption complications

Chronic or recurrent cases may lead to:

  • Weight loss
  • Growth retardation (especially in children)
  • Post-infectious IBS, reactive arthritis, or fatigue lasting weeks to months.

Diagnosis:

  • It is diagnosed through microscopy by the visualisation of the trophozite and cyst.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with type 2 diabetes is admitted with diarrhoea and vomiting. She has noticed small amounts of blood in her stools. The vomiting had commenced one day after having a non-vegetarian diet. The patient's type 2 diabetes is treated with diet alone. Stool cultures taken by the GP reveal Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Campylobacter is a leading cause of diarrhoeal illness, often caused by ingestion of undercooked meat harbouring the pathogen.
  • It is also a major cause of diarrhoea.
  • The use of antibiotic therapy for the management of Campylobacter infection in adults is controversial.
  • Antibiotic of choice in this infection is erythromycin, though ciprofloxacin and tetracycline may also be appropriate.
  • However, appropriate fluid replacement and anti-emetics are initially indicated - most units advocate no antibiotic treatment.
  • Antibiotics are not recommended in patients with nontyphoid Salmonella, Campylobacter, STEC, Aeromonas, or Yersinia, except in severe disease, because they do not hasten recovery or reduce the period of faecal bacterial excretion(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: A 44-year-old with a history of travel presented with fever, mild bloody diarrhoea, which had lasted for two weeks. He had lost 2.5 kg in weight, had occasional lower abdominal cramping discomfort and a painful swelling of his left knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Campylobacter is a leading cause of diarrhoeal illness, often caused by ingestion of undercooked meat harbouring the pathogen. It is also a major cause of traveller's diarrhoea.
  • Abdominal pain is often a prominent feature of the illness, frequently localising to the right iliac fossa. Diarrhoea may be mild or very severe, often with the passage of blood. Symptoms may last a week or longer.
  • The use of antibiotic therapy for the management of Campylobacter infection in adults is controversial.
  • Antibiotic of choice in this infection is erythromycin, though ciprofloxacin and tetracycline may also be appropriate.
  • However, appropriate fluid replacement and anti-emetics are initially indicated - most units advocate no antibiotic treatment.
  • Reactive arthritis and Reiter's syndrome can develop following infection with several enteric pathogens, including Shigella, Salmonella, Campylobacter and Yersinia.

Explanation of other options:

Amoebiasis(Option A) :

  • presents with a gradual onset of lower abdominal pain and milddiarrhoeaa is followed by malaise, weight loss, and diffuse lower abdominal or back pain.
  • Cecal involvement may mimic acute appendicitis. Patients with full-blown dysentery may pass 10-12 stools per day.
  • The stools contain little faecal material and consist mainly of blood and mucus. In contrast to those with bacterial diarrhoea, fewer than 40% of patients with amebic dysentery are febrile. Virtually all patients have heme-positive stools.

Crohn's disease(Option C) is a cause of chronic diarrhoea, which is in contrast to the case given.

Gonococcal sepsis(Option D) will cause prominent constitutional features with a maculopapular rash and may complicate to cause adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: In the diarrhoea associated with cholera toxin, there is activation of which of the following enzyme systems?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cholera toxin has two parts, A and B. B binds while A activates the G protein, which activates adenylate
  • Cholera toxin → ADP-ribosylates Gₛα → activates adenylate cyclase → ↑ cAMP → ↑ Cl⁻ secretion (via CFTR) → watery diarrhoea.
  • Elevated cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) results in unrestricted chloride secretion from villous crypts.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a five-day history of lower abdominal pain and diarrhoea. He has a history of chronic obstructive airways disease (COAD) and has had numerous acute infective exacerbations over the last three months. On examination, he was dehydrated, with a temperature of 38.6°C, a blood pressure of 102/72 mmHg and had a distended, tender abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this clinical scenario, an elderly patient with five days of diarrhea, fever (38.6 °C), distended and tender abdomen, hypotension, dehydration, and systemic toxicity in the setting of chronic disease and recent antibiotic exposure, there is a high suspicion for toxic megacolon, most likely secondary to infectious colitis (e.g., Clostridioides difficile) or severe inflammatory colitis.
  • Plain AXR is useful for diagnosing toxic dilatation and would be the investigation of choice here due to his abdominal distension, so toxic dilatation should be excluded before sigmoidoscopy.
  • A patient with diarrhoea normally has involvement of the distal colon and rectum, and sigmoidoscopy with biopsy is helpful for rapid diagnosis, but should not be performed if toxic dilatation is suspected. Patients with involvement of the right colon usually have little or no diarrhoea.

Explanation of other options:

Chest X-ray(Option A): Useful in ruling out perforation-related free gas under the diaphragm, but it does not assess colonic distension.

Sigmoidoscopy and biopsy(Option C): Generally contraindicated in suspected toxic megacolon due to the risk of colonic perforation.

Stool microscopy(Option D): May help identify pathogens, but does not address the acute complication of megacolon, which requires urgent imaging

questions.text: A vegetarian woman had lunch at a Chinese buffet restaurant. In the evening, she presented with diarrhoea and vomiting. There was no fever. Which of the following is the likely cause of food poisoning in her case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bacillus cereus food poisoning is the general description, although two recognised types of illness are caused by two distinct metabolites.
  • In the above condition, the diarrhoeal type is the suspected one.

Explanation of other options:

Clostridium perfringens(Option B): Usually causes watery diarrhoea and cramps after an incubation of 6–24 hours, typically no vomiting, and less often associated with vegetarian starchy dishes

Escherichia coli (Option C): Often accompanied by abdominal cramps, fever, and sometimes bloody diarrhoea, with a longer incubation of 1–3 days after exposure — not typical in this rapid-onset scenario

Salmonella typhimurium(Option D): Presents with fever, diarrhoea (often bloody), and abdominal pain after several hours to days.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man has returned a few days earlier from a Nile cruise. He has begun suffering from profuse bloody diarrhoea. He opens his bowels several times per day, and there is blood and mucus mixed in with the motion each time. He is also complaining of dull abdominal pain. There is no past medical history of note. On further questioning, he admits to buying fruit from local stalls at the riverside. On examination, he is pyrexial at 37.8°C, and has generalised lower abdominal tenderness. Investigations show:
Haemoglobin 12.1 g/dl(13.5-8)
White cell count 11.4 x 10^9/L (4-10)
Platelets 204 x 10^9/L (150-400)
Sodium 139 mmol/l (134-143)
Potassium 3.9 mmol/l (3.5-5)
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
Stool Blood+
White cells ++
Trophozoites+
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of trophozoites along with bloody diarrhoea and mucus strongly suggests invasive intestinal amoebiasis, most likely due to Entamoeba histolytica, acquired during travel on the Nile and through ingestion of potentially contaminated fruit.
  • Acute amoebic dysentery is managed with a course of oral metronidazole or tinidazole.
  • To be followed by a ten-day course of diloxanide furoate to eradicate colonisation of the gut and not to be used as a first-line therapy until the invasive amoebiasis is treated. (Option C ruled out)
  • IV Cefotaxime is used only if there is secondary bacterial infection or complications. (Option A ruled out)
  • Oral ciprofloxacin is the treatment for amoebiasis, and it can further worsen by masking the disease. (Option B ruled out)
  • With appropriate diagnosis and treatment, mortality from amoebiasis is less than 1%.
  • Amoebic liver abscess may appear at any time from eight weeks after infection, and presents with night sweats, anorexia and right upper quadrant pain.
